ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Conversion of two types of bipolar switching induced by the electroforming polarity in Au/NiO/SrTiO3/Pt memory cells

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Key Laboratory of Photovoltaic Materials of Henan Province and School of Physics and Electronics

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The resistive switching characteristics of Au/p-NiO/n-SrTiO3(STO)/Pt memory cells are investigated. Two types of bipolar switching with opposite polarity coexist in the cell and can be repeatedly adjusted by the electroforming polarity. The conduction mechanisms of low resistance and high resistance states are dominated by electron tunneling and interface barrier effect, respectively. The impact of electroforming polarity on the switching mechanism and the distribution of defects are discussed. The results indicate that these two types of switching originate from a variation of interface barrier respectively at the NiO/STO p–n junction and STO/Pt Schottky contact.

ArticleNote.Heading: Electronic Supplementary Material

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Recently, the resistance-base nonvolatile memory device, frequently called “memristor” and/or “ReRAM,” has attracted intensive attention due to its potential application in next-generation nonvolatile memory [1–3]. This novel memory effect employs the reversal switching between a high resistance state (HRS) and a low resistance state (LRS) denoting logic “0” and “1,” respectively. The resistive switching effect has been observed in capacitor-like structures with various insulating oxides, such as NiO [4], TiO2 [5], HfO x [6], and (Ba,Sr)TiO3 [7], sandwiched by two metal electrodes. From the resistive switching behaviors, diverse switching mechanisms have been proposed: (i) bulk effect based on the creation and disconnection of conductive filaments in the insulated oxides [8–10], and (ii) interface effect wherein resistance change originating from a field-induced variation in interface barrier [11–13]. It is quite often that the switching behavior strongly depends on the material system. Therefore, it should be based on different physical mechanisms in different insulator materials and structures.

SrTiO3 (STO) is a typical perovskite oxide and the excellent switching characteristics have been observed in STO and doped STO [14–20]. These works show that the bipolar switching behavior is closely related with the existence of interface barrier. The change in barrier height and/or width under voltages of different polarities is responsible for the different resistance states [19]. It is well known that interface barrier exists not only in the Schottky contact, but also in p–n junction. Many previous works have been done on the Schottky contact formed at the metallic electrode and STO interface. With this consideration, we deposited NiO/STO double-layer thin films on the Pt (φ:5.65 eV) substrate, which constitutes a memory cell consisting of a p–n junction (at the NiO/STO interface) and a Schottky-like contact (at STO/Pt interface).

Normally, an electroforming process is needed to activate resistive switching in STO [20–22]. During this process, high density of defects can be created through electromigration and the resistance is significantly degraded because oxygen vacancies migration is enhanced along the extended defects. If the surface states density is large enough, the barrier height, i.e., the degree of band bending, is determined by the surface properties of the semiconductor [23]. Whereas the interface defects will dominantly influence the interface barrier model, the defect distribution within the active thin film matrix, impacted by the parameters of electroforming including the applied voltage polarity and the compliance current/voltage, have been claimed to play a crucial role in switching transition [14, 22, 24]. In this study, we investigate the bipolar resistive switching performance of Au/NiO/STO/Pt memory cells under the different polarity of electroforming bias. The experimental results clearly show the coexistence of two different switching characteristics with opposite polarity, which can be reversibly adjusted by the polarity of electroforming bias. The conduction mechanisms of low resistance and high resistance states are dominated by electron tunneling and interface barrier effect, respectively. The impact of electroforming polarity on the switching mechanism and the distribution of defects are discussed. The analyses indicate that these two types of switching originate from a variation of interface barrier, respectively, at the NiO/STO p–n junction and STO/Pt Schottky contact.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: The NiO/STO double-layer thin films were grown on (111) Pt substrates by the pulsed laser deposition technique under oxygen pressure of 12 Pa. In brief, STO films were first deposited on Pt substrates at 700 °C, and then after the substrate has been cooled to 300 °C, it was reheated to 600 °C when NiO films were grown. The deposition time for STO and NiO films is 30 and 10 min, respectively. Finally, the 100 nm thick Au top electrode with the diameter of 100 μm was sputtered onto the as-deposited NiO film through a shadow mask by dc sputtering. The film crystalline structure is determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD), and the I–V characteristics of the Au/NiO/STO/Pt cell are performed by using a Keithley 2400 SourceMeter.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Figure 1(a) shows the XRD patterns of the as-deposited NiO/STO on Pt substrates. The observed diffraction peaks can be indexed to (110) and (211) of STO and (111) of NiO, indicating that the STO and NiO thin films are polycrystalline. The thickness of NiO and STO films is about 100 and 400 nm, respectively, according to the cross-sectional SEM image and energy dispersive X-ray spectra (see supporting information). The device structure and electrical measurement schematic are shown in the inset in Fig. 1(a). In the electrical measurements, the voltage bias that drives the current flowing from Au to STO is defined as positive.
Fig. 1
(a) XRD patterns of the NiO/STO thin films on Pt substrates. The inset is a schematic drawing of the I–V measurement. (b) Rectification I–V curves in pristine Au/NiO/STO/Pt memory cell. The inset is the initial EF with 1 mA CC

The resistance of pristine Au/NiO/STO/Pt memory cells is very large and the cells also show a prominent rectifying I–V behavior, as shown in Fig. 1(b). It is known that the NiO film is a p-type semiconductor and the STO film is an n-type semiconductor, so the rectifying characteristics show p–n junctions formed at the NiO and STO top interfaces. In order to achieve reversible and reproducible switching behavior, the following electroforming processes were required for the pristine Au/NiO/STO/Pt cell. The inset in Fig. 1(b) shows a negative bias sweep with 1 mA compliance current (CC), which is called initial electroforming (EF). During this initial EF procedure, with an increase in the applied bias (to about −10–(−15) V), the current suddenly jumps to the 1 mA CC, and after that the rectifying behavior disappears and a stable bipolar resistive switching behavior with eightwise polarity can be obtained, as shown in Fig. 2(a). When the positive bias is increased, the transition from a high resistance state (HRS) to low resistance state (LRS) will occur, and the increased negative bias can realize the opposite transition of resistance. There is no obvious variation for 50 cycles. The hysteresis is reproducible, reversible, and nonvolatile: Figure 2(b) shows that the cell remains in a LRS/HRS in sweeps after an application of a large positive/negative bias. Figure 2(c) demonstrates the stability of the cell, which was investigated by monitoring the current of HRS and LRS at a read voltage of −0.05 V. The resistance states with an ON/OFF ratio of 7 stay almost unchanged for the 104 s monitoring time. The CC is an important parameter for the initial EF process. Without the CC, the sharp increase in current will result in a hard dielectric breakdown in the active thin films, which leads to the permanent disappearance of the reproducible resistive switching behavior.
Fig. 2
(a) The I–V curves of bipolar resistive switching with eightwise polarity. (b) Both HRS and LRS can be maintained if the bias polarity is not changed, indicating that the resistance state is stable and nonvolatile. (c) The retention of the cell which was investigated by monitoring the current of HRS and LRS for 104 s at a read voltage of −0.05 V

During the initial EF process, relatively large negative bias (about −10–(−15) V) is applied to activate switching behavior. After the initial EF, the prominent rectification behavior observed in the pristine cell disappears and the conductivity is significantly increased. So, the initial EF process is considered to bring two main impacts [22, 25]: (i) High density of defects within the active thin film matrix is created under strong electrical stress, which is associated with the fact that oxygen-vacancy migration (or oxygen diffusion) is significantly enhanced along extended defects. (ii) The positively charged oxygen-vacancies segregated at defects will increase the surface state density, resulting in the decrease/collapse of the interface barrier.

After the initial EF, two types of bipolar switching properties (presented in Fig. 3) can be achieved by adjusting the applied bias polarity. Figures 3(a) and (c) show a positive and negative bias sweep within 2 V, later called as a positive EF and a negative EF, respectively. The positive EF will activate the bipolar resistive switching with counter-eightwise polarity as shown in Fig. 3(b), and the other switching type with eightwise polarity (shown in Fig. 3(d)) is activated by the negative EF process. It is interesting that the polarity conversion of these two switching types can be reversibly and reproducible adjusted by the positive EF and negative EF procedures.
Fig. 3
Two types of bipolar switching can be achieved by adjusting the polarity of EF bias. (a) The positive EF, which results in (b) the bipolar resistive switching with counter-eightwise polarity. (c) The negative EF, which results in (d) the bipolar resistive switching with eightwise polarity

Comparing both types of switching curves in Figs. 3(b) and (d), the similarities are obvious. In positive and negative bias branches, both types of switching exhibit symmetrical I–V curves in the LRS and rectifying I–V curves in the HRS, which imply that these two types of switching transitions should be ruled by the same conductive mechanism. To clarify the conduction mechanism, the fitting results for the I–V curves in Fig. 3(b) at the LRS and HRS are presented in Figs. 4(a) and (b). The I–V curve of the LRS can be fitted as
$I = A\operatorname{sinh} (BU)$ , as shown in Fig. 4(a). Here, A=0.00147 and B=1.93921 are the fitting constants. This function relation is in agreement with characteristics of the electron tunneling model [24]. As for the I–V curve of the HRS, the relation lnI versus V 1/2 can be fitted linearly in high voltage region as shown in Fig. 4(b), indicating that there exist interface barrier in the memory cell [26]. The similar fitting curve can be obtained from Fig. 3(d), not shown here, which shows that the LRS and HRS of bipolar switching with eightwise polarity also follow the electron tunneling and the interface barrier mechanism, respectively. This differs from the bipolar switching of NiO films induced by electrochemical redox reactions [27]. The above analysis indicates that both types of bipolar switching can be explained by a change of interface barrier width and/or height during a voltage sweeping.
Fig. 4
(a) The I–V curve of the LRS of Fig. 3(b) can be fitted as I=Asinh(BU). (b) The relation lnI versus V 1/2 can be fitted linearly at the HRS in high voltage region of Fig. 3(b)

Next, let us take the bipolar switching with eightwise polarity (Fig. 3(d)) as an example to illustrate the switching transition. The positively charged oxygen vacancies pile up at the NiO/STO top interface by the negative EF bias. A variation of net charge in the interface states leads to a modification of barrier width and/or height, because the degree of the band bending depends on a net charge in the interface states [12, 22, 23]. During the voltage sweeping, the further enhancement of negative bias greater than 1.0 V results in the reduction of the currents. This is because of the reduction in the net positive charge by the electron-trapping effect at the interface, which results in the HRS. In contrast, during the coming positive bias sweeping, the trapped electrons are released from the interface. The net positive charge reduces the width of the barrier, which results in the tunneling of electron and makes LRS. Figure 5 shows the band diagram of NiO/STO p–n junction, which illustrates a possible band bending picture under different polarity of bias. Similarly, the bipolar switching with counter eightwise polarity is considered to be caused by a change in the Schottky-like barrier width and/or height at the STO/Pt bottom interface by the electron trapping/detrapping effect.
Fig. 5
The schematic diagram of NiO/STO p–n junction, which illustrates possible band diagrams for the bipolar switching with eightwise polarity. (a) A large amount of electrons is accumulated into the interface states, which increase the width of barrier and make HRS. (b) The net charge in the interface reduce the width of the barrier, which results in the tunneling of electron and make LRS. Open circle means positively charged oxygen vacancy (O.V.) and filled circles mean neutral O.V.

As previously stated, the polarity conversion of these two switching types depends on the polarity of EF bias. If the surface states density is large enough, the barrier height, i.e., the degree of band bending, is determined by the surface properties of the semiconductor [23]. So, the switching polarity should mainly be affected by the states density of the NiO/STO top and STO/Pt bottom interface, which is modified during the positive and negative EF processes. Note that the current in the positive and negative EF are higher than that in the bipolar switching. So, the positive/negative EF might extract trapped oxygen vacancies from the top/bottom interface and accumulate oxygen vacancy into bottom/top interface. The electron trapping/detrapping effect will occur in the corresponding high-density interface. Therefore, the switching polarity is selective with the polarity of EF bias. The electron trapping/detrapping effect plays a major role during the bipolar switching behaviors and the trapped oxygen vacancies might be extracted from the top and bottom interfaces during the positive and negative EF processes, which are mainly due to the different maximum current and bias in these two processes. The pinning of oxygen vacancies at the top (bottom) interface may prevent their drift and the appearance of switching with counter-eightwise (eightwise) curves.

In terms of the above analysis, the series different I–V curves are considered as follows. During the initial EF procedure, the top and bottom interface barrier is considered to collapse due to the creation of high density oxygen vacancy under the strong electrical stress. So, the rectification behavior observed in the initial memory cells disappears. The positively charged oxygen vacancies migrate from the STO interior to the top/bottom interface under negative/positive EF bias, which could modify the surface states density at the top and bottom interface. The electron trapping/detrapping effect will occur at the corresponding high-density interface, which causes the corresponding interface barrier to change. Thus, two types of bipolar switching are implemented.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In summary, the hysteretic I–V characteristics in the Au/NiO/STO/Pt memory cell have been investigated. The cell exhibits two different switching characteristics with opposite polarity, which can be repeatedly and controllable adjusted by the polarity of the EF bias. These two types of bipolar switching can be explained by interface barrier modulation in the NiO/STO or STO/Pt interface, which is caused by electron trapping/detrapping effect at the corresponding high-density interface.
